Sure, here is a possible training program you can use to go from white belt to blue belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) over the course of six months:

1. Week 1: Guard position
* Start by learning the basic guard position, where you are on your back with your legs wrapped around your opponent's waist.
* Practice transitioning from the guard to other positions, such as the closed guard, open guard, and butterfly guard.
* Work on mastering the fundamental guard techniques, such as the hip escape, bridge, and sweep.
2. Week 2: Closed guard
* Focus on improving your closed guard, where you have your opponent's arms controlled and your legs locked around their body.
* Practice breaking your opponent's posture and attacking with submissions, such as the triangle choke and armbar.
* Work on defending against common closed guard passes, such as the stack pass and leg drag pass.
3. Week 3: Open guard
* Spend this week focusing on the open guard, where your legs are not locked around your opponent's body.
* Practice using the open guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the open guard with submissions, such as the omoplata and arm triangle.
4. Week 4: Butterfly guard
* In this week, focus on mastering the butterfly guard, where you have a hook on your opponent's leg with your feet.
* Practice using the butterfly guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the butterfly guard with submissions, such as the armbar and guillotine choke.
5. Week 5: Half guard
* Spend this week learning and improving your half guard, where you have one leg trapped between your opponent's legs.
* Practice using the half guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the half guard with submissions, such as the Kimura and Americana.
6. Week 6: Side control
* In the final week of this program, focus on mastering the side control position, where you are on top of your opponent with your body perpendicular to theirs.
* Practice using side control to maintain the position and prevent your opponent from escaping.
* Work on attacking from side control with submissions, such as the arm triangle and kimura.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to train with a partner if possible. It's also important to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the journey of learning BJJ!
